subject: Re: [junit] Re: Problems with assertEquals()
msgSnippet: Hi, Use like this assertEquals( failure ,object1.getClass(),object2.getClass()); or assertEquals( failure ,object1.hashCode(),object2.hashCode()); for sencond
messageBody:
Hi,

Use like this
assertEquals("failure",object1.getClass(),object2.getClass());
or
assertEquals("failure",object1.hashCode(),object2.hashCode());

for sencond solution we have to make sure that we need make implementation of hashCode()


Kevin Klinemeier <zipwow@...> wrote:

Of course, not having a message may affect the result of your
interactions with other developers. If you don't have a message on
your assertions in my projects, our interaction may revolve around a
large bat. :P


On Tue, 1 Mar 2005 20:22:03 +0100 (MET), Robert Wenner
wrote:
> assertEquals(object1, object2) is also correct, the message doesn't affect
> the result. (See the JUnit source code.)
>
> Checking the class does something completely different.
> I don't think the original poster wanted to compare the classes.
>
> Robert
